meeting_annotations.speaker: Peter Reiners
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hi, I'm Pete. I am a geoscientist at the University of Arizona. I'm interested in subsurface fluid rock systems and sort of the geological record and natural analogs of subsurface systems and to some degree, events in the past that are related to ocean fertilization that may have naturally occurred. So, I'm also associate dean for research in the College of Science at the U of A and I'm also interested in learning from you all about directions that we should be thinking about heading with these exciting technologies and science. Oh, and I'm an observer, so I'm probably going to lay back and not contribute too much. I'm try to hold back.
meeting_annotations.other: He uses a virtual background of a rock formation, which is relevant to his field.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Roger Aines
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think the distinction between observer and participant is a vague one here, so please feel free to contribute. Andrea.
meeting_annotations.other: He is actively encouraging participation from those who identified as observers.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Andrea Hicks
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hi, I'm Andrea Hicks. I'm an assistant professor at the University of Wisconsin-Madison in the Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering. I focus on life cycle assessment of emerging technologies. So my question is always is it sustainable and what are the tradeoffs?
meeting_annotations.other: She clearly and concisely states her expertise and core research question.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Roger Aines
meeting_annotations.transcript: And Jane. Hi Jane, you you win, you're outside.
meeting_annotations.other: He makes a lighthearted comment about the participant's background, fostering a friendly atmosphere.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jane Zelikova
meeting_annotations.transcript: I am winning. I feel really good about being outside and it's sunny. I'm Jane Zelikova. I'm the chief scientist at Carbon180. I'll change my name accordingly so it's clear. Carbon180 is a nonprofit that works specifically on carbon removal and we bring together policy, science, and business to essentially advocate for, support, and scale carbon removal across a whole portfolio of approaches from technological to nature-based. My personal research is, I'm an ecosystem scientist. I think a lot about the carbon cycle, soils, agricultural systems, and climate. So, I am here as an observer, and really excited to meet everyone.
meeting_annotations.other: She mentions she will change her display name to include her organization, showing consideration for the group.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Roger Aines
meeting_annotations.transcript: Okay, I think the next really important thing before we launch in is for someone to volunteer to be the reporter and if we don't get a volunteer then I could pick someone.
meeting_annotations.other: He is moving the meeting agenda forward by assigning a key role.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Venkat Viswanathan
meeting_annotations.other: He volunteers quickly, preventing a potentially awkward pause.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Roger Aines
meeting_annotations.transcript: Thank you, Venkat. You have some experience here. We only want to end up with one slide, so we're really just trying to get some of the highlight points on this. So thank you for...
meeting_annotations.other: He references past experience, indicating this is not the first time this group or format has been used.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Venkat Viswanathan
meeting_annotations.transcript: So maybe I'll just make a couple of comments from previous breakouts that have worked well and I'm trying to figure out how to emulate that in this Zoom environment. So usually what we would have in the breakout is there would be these large sheets of paper or think of it as whiteboards and then we'll just sort of run through these sheets. So I might be able to do that with with the whiteboard here.
meeting_annotations.other: He suggests using the Zoom whiteboard feature to replicate a physical brainstorming process, showing adaptability.
